ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Estimation of electron density and temperature of semiconductor surfaces excited by ultra-short laser pulses

Affiliation.OrgName: Raja Ramanna Centre for Advanced Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
A simple technique, based on the interference principle, to obtain simultaneously the instantaneous electron density and temperature of ultra-short laser-excited semiconductor surface plasma is proposed and demonstrated. The interference of the incident laser and the surface plasmons forms nano-ripples on the surface. From the observed nano-ripple period, one can easily retrieve the density and temperature information. As a demonstration of the technique, the electron density and temperature are obtained for various band gap semiconductor materials based on the experimentally observed nano-ripples using 800 and 400 nm light in various ambient media and incident angles. The electron density estimated varied in the range of 2
$$n_{\mathrm{c} }$$
n c
–10
$$n_{\mathrm{c}}$$
n c
and the corresponding electron temperature in the range 10
$$^{4}$$
4
–10
$$^{5}$$
5
K, depending on the material band gap, the incident laser intensity, the ambient medium, the angle of incidence, and the laser wavelength. The information of the electron density and temperature is useful for choosing laser parameters (like fluence, wavelength, angle of incidence, ambient medium) and target materials (different band gap semiconductors) for obtaining a better size controllability of the nanostructure production. The information can also help one in obtaining essential plasma parameter inputs in the quest for understanding ultra-fast melting or understanding the pre-plasma conditions created by the pre-pulse of ultra-high intensity laser pulses.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Surface modification, nano-structuring, and nano-particle formation by ultra-short pulse with intensity in the range of 10
$$^{10 }$$
10
– 10
$$^{14 }$$
14
W/cm
$$^{2 }$$
2
is a topic of current interest due to the technological advancements for miniaturization of devices and also from the point of view of basic sciences to understand the underlying physical processes [1–4]. Ultra-short pulses with high-repetition rate, working in the above-mentioned intensity range, have been efficiently used for generation of nano-particles [3–6]. Controlling the size of the nano-particles is a crucial aspect for their applications in medicine, nano-optics, surface-enhanced Raman scattering, etc. [7, 8]. The size of the laser-formed nano-particle depends on the surface temperature which is related to laser fluence, wavelength, and the pulse duration [6]. It is, therefore, important to have the surface temperature information for a better size control of the generated particles [9].

It is well known that in the intensity range of
$$10^{10 }$$
10 10
–
$$10^{14 }$$
10 14
W/cm
$$^{2}$$
2
, laser-induced periodic surface structure (LIPSS) is formed [10–12]. Their optical properties depend on their periodicity, which in turn depends on the incident laser parameters such as fluence, incidence geometry, polarization, and material properties such as band gap, melting point, conductivity, and also the ambient medium [13]. A more controlled ripple period and structured surface can be obtained with a prior knowledge of the electron density (
$$n_{\mathrm{e}})$$
n e
)
and temperature (
$$T_{\mathrm{e}})$$
T e
)
for given laser focusing conditions. For such nanostructure growth applications, and also for comprehensive understanding of the physics involved in the studies on laser damage [14–16] and laser ablation [17, 18], it is important to know the laser-generated electron density and temperature during the laser pulse. The final outcome of such studies critically depends on the initial conditions at the surface [14–18]. The knowledge of the electron density and temperature also helps in evaluating various transport properties like the thermal conductivity/resistivity, pertinent for understanding the dynamics of laser–matter interaction for a more controlled growth of the structures [18].

In the experiments with intense ultra-short lasers, the dynamics of the interaction is affected by the pre-pulse forming plasma prior to the arrival of main pulse [19, 20]. The pre-pulse intensity of ultra-high intensity laser pulse is typically
$${>} 10^{10 }$$
>
10 10
W/cm
$$^{2 }$$
2
and the surface conditions are modified on the arrival of the main pulse [19, 20]. Thus
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
information at the target surface, prior to the arrival of the main pulse, is very useful for choosing inputs for surface condition from modeling and simulation point of view [16, 21]. The knowledge of
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
is also helpful in studying the dynamics of laser-shocked surfaces, ultra-fast non-thermal melting, etc., which are studied by time-resolved X-ray diffraction [22–25].

Various methods have been used to estimate the surface temperature and electron density using analytical theory and simulations [9, 16]. Experimental techniques of plasma interferometry [26] and optical reflectance give a fair estimate of electron density. However, they are quite involved experiments and the data interpretation is also quite complicated [23]. Apart from this, values of various material properties like conductivity, specific heat, etc. at the extreme conditions at ultra-short time scales of excitation are still a matter of debate [9, 18, 27]. Further, processes like laser energy coupling, laser incidence geometry, polarization, and ambient medium influence the interaction of the laser with the solid and this cannot be accounted easily using either analytical theory or simulations [6, 13]. Therefore, it is necessary to use a method which is simple and accurate to obtain the instantaneous electron density and temperature of an ultra-short laser excited surface.

In this paper, we discuss a method based on surface plasmon generation on corrugated surfaces on a metal-like surface and dielectric interface to infer the density and temperature at the surface. The method is based on the interference of the incident laser and the generated surface plasmons (SP) which causes a periodic modification of the surface (referred to as the nano-ripples) [13]. In our earlier studies on the nano-ripple formation on various band gap semiconductors we used the 800 nm light and its second harmonic in air and water. It was noted that the ripple period depends on the input laser parameter, material properties, and the surrounding medium [13]. The electron density and temperature information can be obtained from the observed ripple period, as per the procedure outlined later in this paper. In this method of obtaining
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
nano-ripples are formed by first firing a few low-intensity ultra-short pulse laser shots on the planar semiconductor surface and then the ripple period is measured using a scanning electron microscope. From the ripple period, one can have a fairly accurate estimation of the surface plasma conditions prevalent during the laser pulse. This method has an advantage over other methods that here one does not have to speculate about the values of the various material constants and the physical parameters, needed for predicting
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
at extreme conditions [18]. Also,
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
can be found for any angle of incidence, ambient medium, laser wavelength, or band gap, whereas any general analytical or simulation method would become more and more difficult and complex by inclusion of such additional parameters. Finally, since the interference of the laser field and the field of surface plasmon occur only during the laser pulse duration, a snap-shot of the instantaneous density and temperature is obtained [28]. The
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
calculated using the method described in this paper is in fair agreement with other reported works where alternative methods of experiments and simulation were employed [9, 16, 23, 29, 30]. The laser–surface interaction was also simulated using a 1D hydrodynamic code to evaluate the electron density and temperature of the surface plasma. The temperature and density at the target surface during the laser pulse matches well with the values estimated from the experimentally observed ripple period. The information of electron density and temperature is useful for choosing laser parameters (fluence, wavelength, angle of incidence, ambient medium) and target materials (different band gap semiconductors) for obtaining a better control over size of the nano-structure production. The information also helps in obtaining essential plasma parameter inputs in the quest for understanding the ultra-fast melting or understanding the pre-plasma conditions created by the pre-pulse of ultra-high intensity laser pulses.

Section1.Heading: Nano-ripple formation and its relation with temperature and density
Section1.Para:
When a femtosecond pulse interacts with a solid, the laser light is absorbed in the material through both linear and nonlinear absorption processes like multi-photon absorption [14, 15]. These absorption processes generate free electrons giving a transient metallic character to the molten surface [31, 32]. A metallic surface gives rise to the possibility of exciting surface plasmons which are the excitation of longitudinal charge density oscillations. The interference of the SP and incident laser light causes a periodic modulation of the surface. In the following sub-sections, we show that one can retrieve the
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T$$
T
information of ultra-short laser-excited semiconductor surface by observing the nano-ripples.

Section2.Heading: Estimation of the electron density
Section2.Para:
In the first shot on a fresh surface SP [10–12] cannot be generated as the surface plasmon momentum always exceeds the incident light momentum (Fig. 1a). On firing the first shot the rapid localized energy deposition followed by a rapid expansion and cooling of solid density matter can result in nano-particle generation [2–6, 33] making the surface irregular. Firing more shots lead to the nano-ripple formation due to the excitation of the surface plasmons at the roughened solid surface by the incident laser light [34–37]. Therefore, a roughness of appropriate periodicity that satisfies the quasi-momentum matching condition must be present [38]. The required condition is 1
$$\begin{aligned} k_s =k_i \sin \theta +G, \end{aligned}$$
k s
=
k i
sin θ + G ,
where
$$k_{i}$$
k i
is the wave vector of incident laser
$$(k_{i }= 2\pi \mu \sin \theta /\lambda _{\mathrm{L}})$$
(
k i
= 2 π μ sin θ /
λ L
)
, where
$$\lambda _{\mathrm{L}}$$
λ L
is the laser wavelength,
$$k_{\mathrm{s}}$$
k s
is the wave vector of surface plasmon (
$$k_{\mathrm{s}}= 2\pi /\lambda _{\mathrm{s}}),\mu $$
k s
= 2 π /
λ s
) , μ
is the refractive index of the ambient medium, and
$$\left| G \right| $$
G
is the quasi-momentum provided by the rough surface. During the next few shots (Fig. 1b), the laser interacts with the surface of enhanced roughness due to formation of random nano-structures and thus weak excitation of surface plasmon occurs [38]. The subsequent shots fired on the structured surface result in more efficient excitation of the surface plasmons (Fig. 1c). The molten material gets rippled, the period of which depends on laser wavelength, the angle of incidence, and the refractive index of the ambient medium and the surface plasmon (which depends on the electron density of the molten surface). This periodic nano-structure gets frozen once the material cools down as soon as the laser pulse ends, giving rise to the observed nano-ripples

However, structures longer than the laser wavelength can be formed but only at higher angles of incidence and not at normal incidence, as also seen by Loeschner et al. [35], providing more sanctity to the surface plasmon theory of nano-ripple formation.

The method is quite accurate as can be seen from Eq. (6), where the error in estimation of

. The error in measurement in the ripple period is also not very high because typically scanning electron microscopes provide 1–5 nm (
$$\Delta d$$
Δ d
) resolution. It is clear from Fig. 2 that the electron density estimation error will be lesser for smaller ripples and higher for wider ripple periods.

Apart from the issue of accuracy of determination of
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$

It can also be noted from these figures that though the sensitivity of detection decrease slightly at higher angle of incidence, the accuracy of
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
measurement becomes higher especially when wavelength order large ripple period structure is observed.

Section2.Heading: Estimation of temperature
Section2.Para:
The femtosecond pulse excitation of semiconductor surface leads to the production of high density of excited states with a quasi-equilibrium energy distribution. The energy distribution of the carriers over the available states is then described by the Fermi–Dirac distribution with an electron temperature
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
. The number density of the conduction electrons can also be calculated by integrating the product of the density of the conduction electron states with the Fermi function, assuming a quasi-equilibrium energy distribution, i.e. 7
$$\begin{aligned}&n_{\mathrm{e}}\!=\!\int _{E_F }^\infty \rho (E)f(E)dE, \rho (E)\!=\!\frac{8\sqrt{2} \pi m^{3/2}}{h^3}\sqrt{E-E_g }\qquad \end{aligned}$$

$$\sim $$

[10–13, 34–37] . It is intuitive to expect that there should exist a range of intensities for nano-ripple formation, since below this lower limit of intensity the minimum electron density ((
$$\mu ^{2}$$

+1)

for ripple formation is not achieved, and beyond the upper limit of this intensity range laser ablation may blow off a large quantity of material, leaving behind a crater and not imprints of nano-ripple [17]. Thus, this method of
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T$$
T
estimation will be applicable in the intensity range mentioned above where ablation does not take place. It must be mentioned here that ablation causes mass removal followed by hydrodynamical effects [39] and the simplistic model presented in this paper is not applicable in that case. In our experimental condition, the laser intensity was less than the ablation threshold of the semiconductor materials and thus the nano-ripples are formed due to the restructuring of the molten surface which gets frozen after the laser pulse is over.
Fig. 5
Minimum temperature required for nano-ripple formation, for various band gap semiconductors, in air and water, for 800 and 400 nm laser

Section1.Heading: Estimation of electron density and temperature from experimentally observed nano-ripples
Section1.Para:
Based on the method described above we estimated the
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
of femtosecond laser excited semiconductor surfaces from the observed nano-ripple formed by firing multiple laser shots of the Ti:Sa laser using the experimental setup shown in Fig. 6a and b. The following semiconductor materials of narrow (
$$<$$
<
1.5 eV, which is the energy of the incident 800 nm photon) band gap: InAs (0.36 eV), GaAs (1.42 eV), InP (1.35eV); and wide (
$$>$$
>
1.5 eV) band gap materials like GaP (2.3 eV), GaN (3.4 eV), SiC (3.37 eV), and ZnSe (2.82 eV) were used in the experiment. Multiple laser shots from a Ti-sapphire laser with 8 mJ energy, 45 fs pulse duration, and 800 nm wavelength were focused in air on the semiconductor wafers at a fluence in the range of
$$\sim $$
∼
100 mJ/cm
$$^{2}$$
2
–1 J/cm
$$^{2}$$
2
, i.e. around the plasma formation threshold. The general, consistent observations regarding the nano-ripple formation are 1) ripples are always sub-wavelength in size at normal incidence; 2) the ripples are always perpendicular to the laser polarization; 3) nano-particles are formed in the initial shots; 4) the ripple period is larger at higher fluence; 5) the ripple period is larger for the materials having band gap narrower than the incident photon energy compared with that for materials having a wider band gap; 6) a denser ambient medium results in the formation of narrower ripple period; and 7) there is a minimum-intensity threshold for observation of nano-ripples [13]. All these experimental observations are consistent with the theory of surface plasmon-assisted ripple formation [13]. It is the electron density generated at the surface that decides the ripple period. The electron density depends on the target (band gap of the material, its melting point, composition, transport properties, etc.), the ambient medium, and laser parameters like wavelength, fluence, incidence angle, etc. [10–13]. A wider ripple period is indicative of high electron density which may be produced in low band gap material, higher laser intensity, or choosing a geometry wherein the laser energy absorption is higher [10–13]. Similarly, narrow ripple period may be produced by producing less free electrons and this may be so done by using high band gap material, lower laser intensity, or choosing geometry for lower laser energy absorption [10–13]. Thus there and is strong correlation between the ripple period and electron density and this forms the basis of
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
determination.
Fig. 6
Schematic of the experimental setups for nano-ripple formation: a in air, and b in water

Section2.Heading:
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
determination for semiconductors of different band gaps
Section2.Para:
We now obtain the
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
information for semiconductors of different band gaps irradiated by 800 nm and its second harmonic in air. Figure 7a inset shows the nano-ripple period as a function of band gap, for 800 nm laser. Large ripple period is seen for low band gap material, and as the band gap becomes larger than incident photon energy, nano-ripple period decreases. The electron density and temperature are obtained using Eqs. (6) and (9). The electron density decreases with increasing band gap, whereas the temperature decreases for low band gap materials and increases slightly for large band gap materials. Figure 7b inset shows the nano-ripple period as a function of band gap, for 400 nm laser. Large ripple period is seen for low band gap materials and as the band gap becomes larger than incident photon energy, nano-ripple period decreases. The calculated electron density and temperature are shown in the figure. The electron density generated on the surface depends on critically on the band gap and also on the absorption of the ultra-short pulse.
Fig. 7
Density and temperature as a function of the band gap for: a 800 nm, b 400 nm. Insets show the variation of the observed ripple period as a function of the band gap

Section2.Heading:
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
determination for semiconductors irradiated at different angles
Section2.Para:
Next, we obtain the
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
information for semiconductors of different band gaps irradiated by 800 nm laser, as function of incident angle. Figure 8a inset shows the nano-ripple period as a function
$$\theta $$
θ
, in water, in GaAs. The electron density and temperature obtained using Eqs. (6) and (9) are also shown. Figure 8b inset shows the nano-ripple period as a function angle for 800 nm laser, in water, in GaP. The obtained electron density and temperature are also depicted. The increase in the angle of incidence decreases the laser intensity. Decrease in the intensity affects high band gap and low band gap semiconductor differently, as for the former, multi-photon absorption is necessary for free electron generation. The decreasing of laser intensity with the increasing incidence angle will decrease
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
. On the other hand, the reflectivity of
$$p$$
p
-polarized light decrease till the Brewster angle (which is very high for semiconductors) and hence the absorption of laser increases with angle, leading to increase of free charge carriers. The final
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
is determined primarily by the relative dominance of the two factors : “incident intensity” or the “laser absorption”. This difference is apparent in Fig. 8, where the GaP and GaAs show different variation of
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
with
$$\theta $$
θ
. The high band gap material GaP clearly shows the electron density generation drops beyond 30
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
though the absorption increases with angle, implying that the decrease in intensity affects the
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
of the high band gap material, as the multi-photon absorption is highly intensity dependent. Moreover, the low band gap material GaAs clearly shows the electron density generation increases beyond 30
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
, as the absorption increases with angle. Although there is a decrease in intensity at higher angles, linear absorption is still sufficient for creating free electrons. Thus, it can be said that for high band gap materials, the laser intensity is the dominant factor, and for low band gap materials, absorption is the more dominating factor that decides the ripple period.
Fig. 8
Density and temperature as a function of the incidence angle for: a GaAs, and b GaP. The insets show the variation of the observed ripple period with angle of incidence

To summarize, the electron density estimated based on the experimental observations varied in the range of
$$\sim $$
∼
2
$$n_{\mathrm{c} }$$
n c
- 10
$$n_{\mathrm{c}}$$
n c
, and temperature varied in the range of
$$\sim $$
∼
10
$$^{4}$$
4
–10
$$^{5}$$
5
K, depending on material band gap, incident laser intensity, ambient medium, incident angle, and the laser wavelength. The results are in good agreement with other reported works, where other methods of experiments and simulation were used [9, 14–19, 29].

Section2.Heading: Effect of number of laser shots
Section2.Para:
The method of
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
determination described is based on the measurement of ripple period
$$d$$
d
which also depends on the number of laser shots fired at the same place. Figure 9a shows that when InP (low band gap material) is irradiated, nano-particle formed in initial shots making the surface irregular. As shown in Fig. 9b on firing 75 shots nano-ripple with
$$\sim $$
∼
550 nm width is formed and their width increases to
$$\sim $$
∼
650 nm on firing 300 shots as seen from Fig. 9c. Similarly, Gap (high band gap material) forms ripples of
$$\sim $$
∼
170 nm width on firing 50 and 150 shots and ripple period increases almost insignificantly to
$$\sim $$
∼
190 nm for 300 shots as seen from Fig. 9d, e, and f, respectively.
Fig. 9
InP target: a nano-particles in initial 5 shots, b nano-ripples for 75 shots, and c slightly wider nano-ripples for 300 shots. GaP target: d nano-ripples in 50 shots, e similar nano-ripples in 150 shots, f slightly wider nano-ripples for 300 shots

A question arises naturally that when all the parameters are kept same and just the number of laser shots is varied, why should the ripple period change? Various groups have reported different outcomes of ripple period variation with number of shots though in general it is found to slowly decrease monotonically as a function of number of shots [39–41]. On the other hand, in ethanol medium the ripples period remained nearly constant even on firing 100’s of laser shots on silicon substrate [42]. Tsibidis et al. have done theoretical simulations and experiments showing temperature-dependent surface tension gradients and recoil pressure are capable of generating molten material movements that lead to the decrease of ripple period [39]. In their experiment firing the first shot to eighth shot the ripple period was shown to decrease marginally from
$$\sim $$
∼
740 to 725 nm. However there have also been observations of ripple period remaining nearly constant as a function of number of shots even after firing 10
$$^{4}$$
4
–10
$$^{5}$$
5
shots [43]. Also there are few observations which have shown the ripple period to increase slightly with increasing shot number which is similar to our experimental results. For example, it was observed by us and also in some earlier reported experiments that the ripple period shows a very slow increase with increasing number of laser shots [44–46]. As seen from Fig. 9 for both the low band gap material InP and high band material GaP we observed a very insignificant increase in the ripple width. This observation can be explained as follows. During the initial few shots, the ripples are formed depending on the number density of electrons generated. As more and more shots are fired at the same place, the ripples start becoming deeper due to strong surface plasmon excitation. The change of surface morphology results in higher laser energy absorption due to the electric field enhancement in these deep nanostructures [44]. A higher absorption leads to more surface electron density generation as compared with the initial shots. Therefore, since now more electron density is produced, wider ripples are expected. Vorobyev et al. [47] observed that reflectance decrease very insignificantly with the number of shots, implying that absorption (and hence electron density) increases with the number of shots. Thus, on firing 100s and 1000s of shots, a gradual increase of ripple period is expected. It may be noted that the increase in the ripple period with number of laser shots is not a very dramatic; rather a very insignificant increase take place from one shot to another. Thus though the ripple period has some finite variation with number of shots, the electron density and temperature of a semiconductor can be still retrieved from measuring the ripple period as the dependence of ripple period on number of laser shots is not very strong.

The reason for different observations reported in many experiments on ripple period slightly decreasing, remaining constant or meagerly increasing with number of shots can be attributed to two competitive processes that might be taking place during multiple excitation of the surface. The first is the gradual increase of energy absorption (
$$E_{\mathrm{abs}})$$
E abs
)
and the second is the progressive increase of effective volume (
$$V_{\mathrm{eff}})$$
V eff
)
of the surface that interacts with the subsequent pulses (the absorption in a surface plasma takes up to the skin depth
$$\delta =c/\omega _{\mathrm{p}})$$
δ = c /
ω p
)
. Firing first few shots forms a corrugated surface containing lot of nano-particles; therefore, the effective volume of laser surface interaction increases for subsequent pulses. An increase of
$$V_{\mathrm{eff}}$$
V eff
implies that the energy absorbed is distributed over a larger volume, and hence the temperature gets reduced resulting in reduced ripple period. On the other hand, the nano-particle containing rough surface absorbs more light and thus the temperature of the surface is expected to be large resulting in wide ripple period. Therefore, it is the relative dominance of
$$V_{\mathrm{eff} }$$
V eff
and
$$E_{\mathrm{abs}}$$
E abs
that determine whether the ripple period decreases, remains constant or increases with number of shots. The two factors can be combined together by defining a parameter
$$\alpha = E_{\mathrm{abs}}/V_{\mathrm{eff}}$$
α =
E abs
/
V eff
. If
$$\alpha $$
α
increases with number of laser shots ripple period is expected to increase, and if
$$\alpha $$
α
remains constant ripple period is expected to be constant, and if
$$\alpha $$
α
decreases ripple is likely to decrease.
$$\alpha $$
α
should depend on the surface morphology formed by firing multiple shots and this surface modification will depend on the material and laser parameters.

Section1.Heading: Estimation of electron density and temperature using 1D hydrocode
Section1.Para:
To check the validity of the technique described in this work we compared the
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
information obtained based on the experimental results with the evaluations of a hydrodynamic code on laser matter interaction. For this purpose, the simulation of the laser–surface interaction was carried out using a 1D hydrodynamic code (Multifs-1D) [48] to evaluate the electron density and temperature of the surface plasma. The code MULTI-fs is a 1D Lagragian numerical hydro-code based on the MULTI radiation-hydrodynamic code [49] and is devoted to the study of the interaction of ultrashort sub-picosecond laser pulses (in the intensity range from 10
$$^{12 }$$
12
to 10
$$^{17}$$
17
W/cm
$$^{2})$$
2
)
with matter. Hydrodynamics together with laser energy deposition and thermal and radiation transport is solved in one-dimensional geometries. As compared with long nanosecond and picosecond laser pulses, short pulses generate steep gradient plasmas with typical scale lengths considerably below the laser wavelength. In such conditions laser absorption is modeled by solving the 1D Maxwell equations in a high resolution grid. The non-equilibrium between electrons and ions is taken into account, and the electron–ion collision frequency is introduced as an interpolation over a large plasma state range: from cold solid state (where the electron–phonon collision frequency was taken into account) up to hot low-density plasma where electron–ion collision frequency is given by Spitzer formula. The code multifs-1D was used to simulate the hydrodynamics of plasma formed by a femtosecond laser on an InAs target. The plasma temperature and density were deduced at various time steps during and after the laser pulse. As the hydrodynamic codes do not have any provision for considering the band gap of the target material, InAs was used as target as it has a lowest band gap of 0.36 eV amongst all the material used in this study (much less than the laser photon energy 1.5 eV). It had a mass density of 6.674 g/cm
$$^{3}$$
3
and average atomic mass of 99.064 a.m.u. The target was divided into 120 Lagragian cells with cell thickness of 0.5 nm. A temporal resolution of one femtosecond was chosen for time intervals near the peak of pulse, while larger time steps of 100 fs were considered for time intervals before and after the laser pulse. The laser pulse (
$$\lambda _{\mathrm{L}} \quad \sim $$
λ L
∼
800 nm) had Gaussian shape with 45 fs FWHM and intensity of
$$3 \times 10^{12}$$
3 ×
10 12
W/cm
$$^{-2}$$
- 2
. The plasma temperature at the peak and at the end of the laser pulse at the target surface was found to be 3.32 and 2.21 eV, respectively, whereas the electron density at the surface was found to be 12
$$n_{\mathrm{c}}$$
n c
and 8.8
$$n_{\mathrm{c}}$$
n c
at the peak and at the end of the pulse, respectively. The temperature (2.21 eV : 25636 K) and density (8.8
$$n_{\mathrm{c}})$$
n c
)
at the InAs target surface at the end of the laser pulse matches quite well with the temperature (2.02 eV: 23400 K) and density(9.2
$$n_{\mathrm{c}})$$
n c
)
estimated from the experimentally observed ripple period (
$$d= 750$$
d = 750
nm).

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para:
We have described a simple technique to obtain simultaneously the electron density and temperature of laser-excited semiconductor surface. This method has a definite advantage over other methods that here one does not have to speculate about various material constants and physical parameter values needed for predicting
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
at extreme conditions. Also,
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
can be found for any angle of incidence, ambient medium, laser wavelength, or band gap. The electron density estimated varied in the range of
$$\sim $$
∼
2
$$n_{\mathrm{c} }$$
n c
–10
$$n_{\mathrm{c}}$$
n c
and the corresponding temperature varied in the range of
$$\sim $$
∼
10
$$^{4}$$
4
–10
$$^{5}$$
5
K. This is in good agreement with other reported works and simulations done by us using 1D hydrodynamic code (for InAs). The study can be helpful in size control of the nano-particles and nano-ripples produced by ultra-short pulses. The minimum electron density and temperature required for observing nano-ripple formation have been calculated for various semiconductors. This method is like the interferometric method used to infer plasma density and temperature information with the only difference that here it is not the fringe shift but the fringe imprint on the surface which carries the information of
$$n_{\mathrm{e}}$$
n e
and
$$T_{\mathrm{e}}$$
T e
. Moreover, in normal interferometry using visible laser, the maximum density that can be probed is equal to the critical density where the laser light gets reflected, whereas in the present method information of supercritical densities can be obtained.
